context:
Speaker: Look! It's snowing. Winter is here at last.
Listener: It's really cold today.
Speaker: Yes, you have to get used to it. The weather's going to be like this for the next three months.
Listener: Then I'm going to Florida. Can you tell me about your weather diary? Why do you make notes about the different types of weather?
Speaker: Because it's interesting to see what the weather is like at different times and on different days. For example, we had very interesting weather on the 28th of April.
Listener: Really?
Speaker: Yes. On the 28th of April, it was sunny while I was eating my breakfast. I'm sure everybody thought it would be a sunny day.
Listener: What happened?
Speaker: At lunch, the sky became cloudy. In the afternoon, at four, the sky was black and it rained heavily. That was really an unusual day.
Listener: I think you should be a weather reporter. You know a lot about the weather.
Speaker: Thanks. I want to be a weather reporter when I finish school. It's an exciting job.
question: How does Listener (or others) feel because of what Speaker just said?
a1: the listener is confident about the speaker becoming a weather reporter very soon.
a2: impressed by speaker's interest in the weather and their career aspiration.

context:
Listener: Good morning. Sit down please, Mr. Johnson.
Speaker: Thank you, madam.
Listener: I have read your letter here. You seemed to have done very well at school. Can you tell me something about your school work?
Speaker: As you can see, my strongest subjects were arts subjects. My best subject was history and my second best was geography. However, my favorite subject was math, and the results I got in the math paper were quite reasonable.
Listener: That's true. Now, can you tell me why you think these subjects will help you in this job?
Speaker: Well, madam, I understand that you manufacture computers, prepare software, and advise clients on how to use them. Is that right?
Listener: That's right.
Speaker: And I've been told that working with computers needs a logical mind rather than great skills in mathematics. That's especially true, I believe, when it comes to writing programs. So I think my results show that I have some ability in logic and in mathematics as well.
Listener: So, you would like to write material for computers, would you?
Speaker: Yes, madam. That's what interests me most about computers - writing programs, but I think the computer industry itself is still expanding enormously. I'm sure that career prospects in the industry would be very good no matter what sort of job I went into.
Listener: I see, well, thank you. I've enjoyed our talk. We'll be writing to you.
Speaker: Thank you, madam. Good morning.
question: How does Listener (or others) feel because of what Speaker just said?
a1: uncertain about whether writing programs is the best fit for speaker's talents and the company's needs.
a2: the speaker was glad after having a conversation with mr. johnson.

context:
Speaker: Did you watch the TV special about barnacles last night?
Listener: No, I missed it. What did you learn about them?
Speaker: That they glue themselves to rocks in the ocean, shortly after birth. They also stay in the same place forever.
Listener: Right, have you ever tried removing one of those things? It would be easier to chip the rock away than to get the barnacles off.
Speaker: Exactly, and that's why scientists are trying to figure out what the barnacles glue is made of. It's considered one of the strongest adhesives in nature.
Listener: And it would have the advantage of being able to work on wet surfaces too.
Speaker: Precisely, and because it's natural protein, it probably wouldn't be harmful to people like so many synthetic glues in use today.
